trans-unit.source: Contains a collection of <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> controls used to track and manage related groups of controls.
This class cannot be inherited.

The WebPartCollection class is a read-only collection of controls, typically used by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZoneBase> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> controls to manage sets of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls.

A <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> control uses a WebPartCollection object to keep a list of all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on a page, whereas a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZoneBase> control uses a WebPartCollection object to track the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls that it contains.

> [!NOTE] > The WebPartCollection collection contains both <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls and other server controls (such as user controls, custom controls, and ASP.NET controls) that are placed in <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZoneBase> zones and used as part of Web Parts applications.

So, for example, if you have a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZone> zone in a page, and within it you declare a custom <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control and the ASP.NET <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Calendar> control, both controls will be in the WebPartCollection collection referenced by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.WebParts%2A> property.
The WebPartCollection object exists so that the Web Parts control set can work with strongly typed collections.

Similarly, if you want to perform mass operations on a set of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls, you can get a reference to a WebPartCollection object using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.WebParts%2A> property.
For example, you might want to loop through all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on a page and change their appearance in some way.
Even though the WebPartCollection object is read-only, you can make programmatic changes to the properties of the underlying controls referenced in the collection.
Initializes an empty new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection"></xref> class.
The WebPartCollection constructor initializes an empty instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> class.
The object itself is read-only and has no method to add individual <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls to it; therefore, you will have little occasion to use this constructor.

Initializes a new instance of a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection"></xref> object by passing in an <xref:System.Collections.ICollection> collection of <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> controls.

The WebPartCollection constructor initializes an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> class by passing in a collection of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls.

Although a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object is read-only and there is no method for adding individual controls to it, you can create your own <xref:System.Collections.ICollection> collection of controls, and pass that to the WebPartCollection constructor.
This enables you to create custom collections and perform bulk operations on them.
You can also access the underlying controls in the collection and change their property values programmatically.
An <xref:System.Collections.ICollection> of <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> controls.
webParts is .
Returns a value indicating whether a particular control exists in the collection.

The Contains method enables you to check a particular <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> object and determine whether it is part of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> that is checked to determine whether it is in the collection.
A Boolean value that indicates whether a particular control is in the collection.
Copies the collection to an array of <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> objects.

The CopyTo method is useful when you want to assemble a custom array that can contain the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object, a subset of those controls, or a superset of those controls.
An array of <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> objects to contain the copied collection.
The starting point in the array at which to place the collection contents.
Returns the position of a particular member of the collection.

The IndexOf method is useful if you have multiple <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on a Web Parts page, and you need to know the ordinal position of one control relative to the others.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> that is a member of the collection.
An integer that indicates the position of a particular object in the collection.
Returns a member of the collection based on its position in the collection.

The Item indexer allows you to access the underlying <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object by index, and change their property values or call methods.
The index of a particular <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> control in a collection.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> at the specified index in the collection.
Returns a member of the collection based on a unique string identifier.

The Item indexer enables you to access a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object according to a unique identifier.
> [!NOTE] > The Web Parts control set performs case-insensitive matching on this property, so case sensitivity is not part of a unique `id` value.
The Item property also works to identify members of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object in some specialized cases.

In the case of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> controls, the indexer is able to match the identifier for the underlying child control wrapped by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> control.

In the case of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart> controls, the indexer matches the identifier for the control based on a case-insensitive comparison of the `id` parameter and either the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart.OriginalID%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart.GenericWebPartID%2A> property values.
The unique identifier for a particular <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> control in a collection.
The first in the collection whose ID equals the value of id.
